awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Cultivating Scientific Mindsets in the Machine Learning Era
awd_abstract_narration:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is woven into the fabric of everyday life. There is currently an enormous skills gap in AI for the future workforce. Limited AI learning opportunities among K-12 students and professional development opportunities for teachers may lead to AI inequity in the workforce and education. This project addresses these challenges by introducing Machine Learning (ML) as a discovery tool for data-driven scientific inquiry in K-12 STEM classroom. The project focuses on creating and studying a novel programming-free and visual-based ML-powered learning environment. It aims to enable high school students and teachers with limited mathematical, programming and data skills to discover complex scientific phenomena and ask big questions from thought-provoking patterns hidden in real-world data. Researchers will include high school students from marginalized backgrounds in STEM throughout the research activities and engage in outreach in collaboration with the David T. Kearns Center for Diversity and Leadership at the University of Rochester. This project will contribute to NSF’s missions on promoting inclusion in next-generation STEM education, and advance K-12 AI literacy as a driving force of national prosperity. 

     Researchers will carry out three synergistic research activities: (1) creating a ML-powered visual learning environment that utilizes a combination of novel glyph-based data visualization and analogical learning process to mitigate the steep learning curve of ML and multi-dimensional pattern discovery for high school learners; (2) adopting a co-design approach to include K-12 STEM teachers and data science experts in creating ML-powered scientific inquiry activities; and (3) iteratively evaluating the effectiveness of the new learning environment in supporting three key learning goals for high school students: multi-dimensional pattern discovery, ML concepts and methods around clustering and classification, and pattern-inspired scientific inquiry through question asking, hypothesis generation, explanation and argument. Findings of this project will advance our knowledge on the design and pedagogical guidelines of ML-powered visual learning environments that minimize cognitive load for novice K-12 AI learners. The resulting novel learning environment, and ML-powered scientific inquiry activities will be made publicly available.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project envisions a future where high school students use Machine Learning (ML) as everyday classroom tools to explore science and uncover hidden patterns in data. Our goal is to make these advanced technologies understandable and easy to use for students and teachers, even those without a background in programming or data science.

To bring this vision to life, we designed a programming-free, visual-based online learning tool that introduces high school students and teachers to basic ML concepts. Instead of requiring coding or complex math, our tool helps users recognize patterns in data through intuitive visualizations. One of our key innovations is a "face glyph" visualization that turns data into facial features (Fig. 1). For example, in an ecology lesson, the number of beetle species could be represented by the size of a character’s cheeks. Because the human brain is naturally drawn to faces, this approach makes it easier for students to analyze and understand complex data. We also improved the face glyph design with several features to help students interpret data patterns more accurately and in the target context and reduce attention bias with their visual inspection. To contrast the benefit of the face glyph design with more traditional glyph visualization, we also introduced a segment-style “star glyph” as a baseline for comparison. Findings of a study with 25 high school students show that these improvements helped students better analyze data in context, avoid missing data attributes, and produce a global understanding of the dataset.  

The second phase of our project focused on helping teachers integrate ML into their classrooms. Many educators find it challenging to use ML-driven tools because they require technical and pedagogical knowledge and specialized training. To bridge this gap, we developed a web-based authoring tool (Fig. 2), allowing teachers to create interactive scientific inquiry learning activities using ML without programming skills. With this tool, teachers can design activities by selecting ML functions—such as grouping similar data, identifying outliers, or making predictions—and combining them with traditional scientific inquiry steps like forming hypotheses, analyzing results, and drawing conclusions. We worked with 14 middle and high school teachers in a co-design workshop. They used the tool to create a range of ML-powered scientific inquiry learning activities, covering both subjects in STEM fields, such as physics, biology, environmental science, and engineering, and social sciences, such as history, government, geography, and psychology. The study confirmed the tool's usefulness in supporting teachers to use ML to help students discover patterns in data, compare real-world results to predictions, and refine their scientific reasoning. This approach introduced students to ML concepts and encouraged critical thinking and deeper engagement with the subject matter.

This project is a step toward closing the K-12 AI education gap and ensuring that all students, regardless of background, can explore the power of data and ML in meaningful ways. By making ML-based data analysis tools easy to use and user-friendly, this project helps high school students gain hands-on experience working with data, preparing them for a world where AI literacy is increasingly important. Teachers, in turn, can integrate ML technology into their lessons without needing advanced math and technical expertise. Our findings suggest that this approach could transform K-12 education, helping students develop key AI, data analysis, and scientific inquiry skills. As AI continues to shape industries and economies, equipping students with these skills early on will better prepare them for future careers and create a more AI-literate society.
